utterances: Unidentified Female #1: Okay, those who do not have ear pieces...
Last weekend the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, or MOCA, ran out of amplifying devices for a tour of its show WACK!
Art and the Feminist Revolution.
The show documents work between 1965 and 1980 and includes well over 100 artists, several of whom were there for the tour.
Many told stories of how their art was poorly received.
Mary Kelly's piece, called ""Post Partum Document,"" which was displayed in London in 1976, is a detailed account of the first five years of caring for her son.
And when I kept the dirty nappies, as they say in England - the dirty diapers here - it caused a huge outrage.
Kelly says ""Post Partum Document"" and her other works on display, which use text and film, comment on the invisibility of women's labor.
That try to understand what women's lives were like at that time and what it meant to look after children and the whole - all of the problems about domestic labor, for instance.
Many pieces in the show explore the female body.
While some of the work is no longer controversial, other pieces probe expressions of female sexuality so explicitly that they continue to provoke.

Tracy Wolverton(ph), who worked with the Lesbian Arts Project in the 1970s, told the large group of people on the tour how they were very consciously using art to break down all kinds of barriers for women.
One of the things that's so important to know about feminist art is that art and life were no longer these separate things.
We were changing our lives as we were making the art.
The MOCA exhibition has the sense of a sprawling romp through 15 years of exploration and inquiry into self - history, gender roles, sexuality, community, identity.
That same exploration was brought to the materials and forums used to make art.

There are collages, film and video documentation of performances, pieces that use latex, hair, rubber, mattresses, string, and there are traditional paintings and drawings that challenge the male point of view.
Sylvia Sleigh, now in her 90s, remained a figurative painter throughout.
But her piece ""The Turkish Bath"" stirred up controversy anyway.
It's a satirical painting of male artists and critics in a bath depicted in the traditional way that women had been, as objects of desire.
(Unintelligible) desire part is the object, which is not really nice, and I wanted to paint men in a way that I appreciated them and they were dignified and intelligent and nice people.
This international show is unprecedented in its scope and size, says Catherine Lord, a writer, artist and professor of studio art at University of California at Irvine.
Thousands of homes may be affected.
They have owners but they've never responded to letters or phone calls.
The doors of the houses are still sealed from the storm.
Sewage flows through open channels, children bathe in cattle troughs.
Electricity is off more than it's on.
All this not far from Kahuta, where Pakistan spent billions to develop its nuclear weapons program.
Zahra can't solve all this.
But she's expanding her programs to another nearby village, where 25-year-old Zarmina Janisar lives in a one-room mud and brick house with her husband and seven children.
They're farm laborers.
Exhausted, Zarmina holds a newborn, who's brought more worries than joy.
(Foreign language spoken)
She doesn't know how she will feed or educate her kids.
(Soundbite of coughing)
All these problems, we all have skin problems because of dirty water.
Zahra says just about every family here suffers from either hepatitis C or serious gastrointestinal problems.
Even if we give them the medicine, the next day they'll go back and use the dirty water to take showers and the problem starts again.
So it's a very vicious circle.
So unless and until the problem - the water problem is soon solved, there's no way we can help them out.
And we are fighting with the government, also.
Until Zahra recently opened a clinic to service the area, there was no ready access to a doctor.
Infant mortality is amongst the highest in the world, 10 times that of the U.S., twice that of neighboring India.
With most families here living on a dollar a day, she and the new physician are tackling the delicate issue of contraception.
The women were receptive.
The big question was how to deal with the men.
I know it's dangerous.
I know it's very difficult to talk to the men on this subject.
But I thought, let me try it.
Let me see what the reaction should be.
Their reaction was better than she dared hope.
Many women are now coming to the clinic along with their husbands.
Zahra and the doctor insist on that because if the women do it on their own and are caught, they risk being beaten or worse.
Twenty-five-year-old Zarmina says she, too, would like help.
Zahra quietly talks to her husband, explaining Islam is not against spacing children.
He says, okay.
Anne Garrels, NPR News, Barakau.
On October 7th, 2001, that's five years ago tomorrow, the U.S.
led coalition began bombing Afghanistan.
Weeks later, the ruling Taliban had fled.
Now they're back.
And one battle, for one village in the Pashtun heartland, may hold the key to which way this new fight for Afghanistan will go.
The village is called Panjwai.
It sits on the edge of the former Taliban stronghold of Kandahar, in the deep southern part of the country.
It's an easy drive from the Pakistan border.
NATO forces took on the Taliban there last month and the Taliban took a stand.
A number of Canadian troops were killed.

Renee Montagne has been reporting from Afghanistan, and earlier this week, in Kabul, she sat down with the man who wrote the book on this group, Ahmed Rashid, author of Taliban: Militant Islam, Oil, and Fundamentalism in Central Asia.
If you had to sketch out how things stand in the south, how would you describe it?
Well, in southern Afghanistan there is a full scale insurgency.
Which, at least in two provinces, Kandahar and Helmand, is probably - could be termed a war.
There are thousands of troops battling thousands of Taliban.
Something like 7,000 to 8,000 Taliban are in the field at the moment in southern Afghanistan, scattered over four to five provinces.
They're very well-armed.
They have stood and fought.

The Canadians have just recently fought the battle in Panjwai, just outside Kandahar - and the Taliban were attempting to set up a base in Panjwai by which they could then, ultimately, try and capture Kandahar.
One of the great successes NATO claimed was Panjwai.
Was it a success, and why was it such a hard-fought battle?
Panjwai is a very rich agricultural area of vineyards, just outside Kandahar.
The Taliban have been assembling there for many months.
They have brought in a lot of ammunition and food.
They've set up a training camp.
They've set up an explosives area where people were being trained in suicide bombs.
And really, this was an attempt to make a move on Kandahar, which is the largest city in southern Afghanistan.
And I think what happened was that the Canadians, of course, moved in, in force.
They surrounded this Panjwai area.
There was very heavy fighting for 10-15 days.
There was literally hand-to-hand fighting.
But eventually, hundreds and hundreds of Taliban were killed.
So in that sense, it certainly was a success.
It was a victory.
But the Taliban will be back.
They will probably be harassing the Canadians now with suicide bombing.
So, you know, it's certainly - the battle may be won, but the war is still going on.
And in that battle, the Taliban were reinforced byâ€¦
There were large numbers of reinforcements that came in on pickup trucks from the Pakistan border.
In fact, a lot of these pickup trucks were being monitored by satellites and by American drones.
And a lot of them were bombed.
And in fact, a lot of the casualties that the Taliban took were from these reinforcements, which were being bombed from the air.
NATO has said that, in a sense the Taliban made a misjudgment in the south, in Kandahar, in taking them on in terms of straightforward fighting, as opposed to guerrilla activity.
It's very difficult to actually define success in a war like this.
There is no doubt that the Canadian forces have defeated the Taliban.
And the Canadians are now trying to do what they had promised to do in the beginning, which was reconstruction, development, etc.
But the problem is that this is an insurgency, which is based from Pakistan.
The command and control is in Pakistan.
And this is an insurgency based largely amongst the Pashtun tribes.
You have unlimited manpower.
There are 14 million Pashtuns in Pakistan, all potential recruits for the Taliban.
Now, the problem is, NATO can't just carry on killing thousands and thousands of Pashtuns.
So it's a very, very complex game that is going on in the south.
Thank you very much for joining us.
Thank you.
That's Ahmed Rashid, author of Taliban, speaking with Renee Montagne earlier this week in Kabul.
On Wednesdays, we focus on the workplace.
Today, more buyouts in Detroit.

Nobody's ever put these objects and these video works and these documentations of performances in the same room so that you can look at the relations between the work to see what the work actually does, what it's like.
While the work in the show varies in quality, the exhibition's curator, Connie Butler, believes the feminist art movement was the most influential force in art in the last 50 years.
She says the forms and themes taken up by many of today's most successful artists, male and female, owe a debt to these women.
The arts that I was the most interested in were referring rather directly to this work: Jeanine Antony(ph), Beverly Simms(ph), Bob Gover(ph), Matthew Barney.
And I felt that all of us kind of collectively were looking back at this period without any real knowledge of what had gone on and with a sort of, you know, searching around for information.

While some artists in the exhibition are little known today, others have recognizable names: Cindy Sherman, Judy Chicago, Yoko Ono, the filmmaker Sally Potter, and Louise Bourgeois, just to name a few.
Others were less successful.
Still, their impact is felt by younger artists.
In response to the show at MOCA, students at the California Institute of the Arts, known as CalArts, are organizing an exhibition of their own feminist work.
Last weekend dozens of students hung art, put up installations and rehearsed performances in the school's atrium.
The work on display is certainly influenced by the artists of two and three generations ago.
Alana Mann(ph), a 26-year-old MFA student, is one of the exhibition's curators.
There are some pieces in our show that are drastically different than work that was made then, and then there's some pieces that are very - you can see a very clear connection.
The connection can be seen in a video by Lindsay Foster in which a woman in a kitchen is relentlessly combing her long hair.
In a series by Angie Cardone(ph) of weapons knitted from wool.
Still, Mann says many of her contemporaries are uncomfortable calling themselves feminists.
